title: Why People Fly the Black American Flag and What It Means

steps.title: A black American flag means the person flying it is willing to defend themselves.
steps.content: A black American flag means the person flying it is willing to defend themselves. It has different meanings for different people and is usually flown by conservatives. For some, it means they aren’t afraid of defending themselves. For others, it means they will give no mercy to their enemies and would rather die than be taken prisoner themselves. [1] X Research source This goes back to the No Quarter rule of the pirates, who flew black flags with a skull and crossbones when they wanted to tell other ships they would kill anyone they captured. [2] X Research source

steps.title: People usually fly the black American flag to tell others that they won't tolerate threats.
steps.content: People usually fly the black American flag to tell others that they won't tolerate threats. Some fly the black American flag to let other people know they aren’t afraid to defend themselves. Others fly it to tell people that they don’t hold space for perceived enemies and aren’t willing to surrender against people who threaten them. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Black American flags were created by artist Jasper Johns.
steps.content: Black American flags were created by artist Jasper Johns. They first started popping up in the 1970s, when Johns began painting variations of the classic red, white, and blue flag. [4] X Research source They didn’t become popular until 2021 after going viral on social media. [5] X Research source Black American flags are rumored to have been flown by the Confederates in the Civil War, but that is false. They flew the “Confederate flag,” a red battle flag with a star-studded, blue diagonal cross. [6] X Research source Historians say Confederates wouldn’t have flown Union flags. If they did capture a Union flag, it was a trophy. [7] X Research source

steps.title: The black flag emoji usually represents protests, rebellion, or non-conformity.
steps.content: The black flag emoji usually represents protests, rebellion, or non-conformity. You can use the black flag emoji if you’re in protest of something, if you’re feeling rebellious, or want to show that you won’t conform. You can also use it when you’re having a bad day or want to show that you’ve reached the end of your rope. [8] X Research source This goes back to the waving of black and red flags to signify the end of a race. [9] X Research source Anarchists may use the black flag emoji to identify themselves on social media. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Black Flag
steps.content: Black Flag The all-black flag has different meanings based on who’s flying it. For some, it represents anarchy. For others, it is meant to be the opposite of the white flag, which is the worldwide symbol for surrender. [11] X Research source It is also used in times of mourning [12] X Research source In racing, it is used to represent an on-track infraction and tells drivers when they need to leave the track. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Black and White Flag
steps.content: Black and White Flag The black and white flag is often used to represent freedom, unity, and justice. It has almost exclusively been used to express political resistance and the fight for freedom, justice, and equality. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Jolly Roger
steps.content: Jolly Roger Also known as the pirate flag, this was flown by pirates in the 18th century. It was used to tell the ship being approached to immediately surrender or else risk the execution of everyone on board. [15] X Research source Pirates usually hoisted this flag right before approaching a ship. Due to the pirates’ “No Quarter” policy, the Jolly Roger has become associated with the all-black American flag.

steps.title: Pan-African Flag
steps.content: Pan-African Flag This flag is known to represent Black power. It was designed by Marcus Garvey, a political activist, in 1920 and serves as a symbol of pride and coalition among people of African descent.
